#Text=PSAMS TRAVEL CAR
#Text=She would have put ‘ travelling carriage ’ , but she made the letters too big , so there was no room .
#Text=The bag was made INTO a bag with old Nurse ’s sewing machine , and the strings of it were Anthea ’s and Jane ’s best red hair ribbons .
#Text=At tea-time , when the boys had come home with a most unfavourable report of the St james ’s Park ducks , Anthea ventured to awaken the Psammead , and to show it its new travelling bag .
#Text=‘ Humph , ’ it said , sniffing a little contemptuously , yet at the same time affectionately , ‘ it ’s not so dusty . ’

#Text=The Psammead seemed to pick up very easily the kind of things that people said nowadays . For a creature that had in its time associated with Megatheriums and Pterodactyls , its quickness was really wonderful .
#Text=‘ It ’s more worthy of me , ’ it said , ‘ than the kind of bag that ’s given away with a pound of plaice .
#Text=When do you propose to take me out in it ? ’
#Text=‘ I should like a rest from taking you or us anywhere , ’ said Cyril .
#Text=But Jane said --
#Text=‘ I want to go to Egypt .
#Text=I did like that Egyptian Princess that came to marry the King in Babylon .
#Text=She told me about the larks they have in Egypt .
#Text=And the cats .
#Text=Do let ’s go there .
#Text=And I told her what the bird things on the Amulet were like .
#Text=And she said it was Egyptian writing . ’
#Text=The others exchanged looks of silent rejoicing at the thought of their cleverness in having concealed from Jane the terrors they had suffered in the dungeon below the Euphrates .
#Text=‘ Egypt ’s so nice too , ’ Jane went on , ‘ because of Doctor Brewer ’s Scripture History .
#Text=I would like to go there when Joseph was dreaming those curious dreams , or when Moses was doing wonderful things with snakes and sticks . ’
#Text=‘ I do n’t care about snakes , ’ said Anthea shuddering .
#Text=‘ Well , we need n’t be in at that part , but Babylon was lovely !
#Text=We had cream and sweet , sticky stuff .
#Text=And I expect Egypt ’s the same . ’
#Text=There was a good deal of discussion , but it all ended in everybody ’s agreeing to Jane ’s idea .
#Text=And next morning directly after breakfast ( which was kippers and very nice ) the Psammead was invited to get into his travelling carriage .
#Text=The moment after it had done so , with stiff , furry reluctance , like that of a cat when you want to nurse it , and its ideas are not the same as yours , old Nurse came in .
#Text=‘ Well , chickies , ’ she said , ‘ are you feeling very dull ? ’
#Text=‘ Oh , no , Nurse dear , ’ said Anthea ; ‘ we ’re having a lovely time .
#Text=We ’re just going off to see some old ancient relics . ’
#Text=‘ Ah , ’ said old Nurse , ‘ the Royal Academy , I suppose ?
#Text=Do n’t go wasting your money too reckless , that ’s all . ’

#Text=She cleared away the kipper bones and the tea-things , and when she had swept up the crumbs and removed the cloth , the Amulet was held up and the order given -- just as Duchesses ( and other people ) give it to their coachmen .
#Text=‘ To Egypt , please ! ’ said Anthea , when Cyril had uttered the wonderful Name of Power .
#Text=‘ When Moses was there , ’ added Jane .
#Text=And there , in the dingy Fitzroy Street dining-room , the Amulet grew big , and it was an arch , and through it they saw a blue , blue sky and a running river .
#Text=‘ No , stop ! ’ said Cyril , and pulled down jane ’s hand with the Amulet in it .
#Text=‘ What silly cuckoos we all are , ’ he said .
#Text=‘ Of course we ca n’t go .
#Text=We dare n’t leave home for a single minute now , for fear that minute should be THE minute . ’
#Text=‘ What minute be WHAT minute ? ’ asked Jane impatiently , trying to get her hand away from Cyril .
#Text=‘ The minute when the Queen of Babylon comes , ’ said Cyril .
#Text=And then everyone saw it .
#Text=For some days life flowed in a very slow , dusty , uneventful stream .

#Text=The children could never go out all at once , because they never knew when the King of Babylon would go out lion hunting and leave his Queen free to pay them that surprise visit to which she was , without doubt , eagerly looking forward .
#Text=So they took it in turns , two and two , to go out and to stay in .
#Text=The stay-at-homes would have been much duller than they were but for the new interest taken in them by the learned gentleman .
#Text=He called Anthea in one day to show her a beautiful necklace of purple and gold beads .
#Text=‘ I saw one like that , ’ she said , ‘ in -- ’
#Text=‘ In the British Museum , perhaps ? ’
#Text=‘ I like to call the place where I saw it Babylon , ’ said Anthea cautiously .
#Text=‘ A pretty fancy , ’ said the learned gentleman , ‘ and quite correct too , because , as a matter of fact , these beads did come from Babylon . ’
#Text=The other three were all out that day .
#Text=The boys had been going to the Zoo , and Jane had said so plaintively , ‘ I ’m sure I am fonder of rhinoceroses than either of you are , ’ that Anthea had told her to run along then .
#Text=And she had run , catching the boys before that part of the road where Fitzroy Street suddenly becomes Fitzroy Square .
#Text=‘ I think Babylon is most frightfully interesting , ’ said Anthea . ‘ I do have such interesting dreams about it -- at least , not dreams exactly , but quite as wonderful . ’
#Text=‘ Do sit down and tell me , ’ said he .
#Text=So she sat down and told .
#Text=And he asked her a lot of questions , and she answered them as well as she could .
